page.title: 04Former days at Hauxwell
page.content: My home was in South Shields, but in August 1923 I got work as housemaid to Colonel Wade-Dalton at Hauxwell Hall.A train ran to Constable Burton in those days. I was met by a horse and trap. I remember the road to Hunton was a cart track with deep ruts in the middle! Hauxwell was really feudal. Everybody in the village worked on the estate so it was self-supporting. Each cottage had an acre and a cow. Churning days were anxious days then, especially if the butter would not come. It was sold at Leyburn or shaped into dainty pats for shows. The Colonel always gave a New Year party at the hall for workers and wives. We made our own pleasures mostly;whist drives,dances or concerts in school. The Reading Room and quoits were for MEN ONLY. Once a German band came here with a dancing bear! Village life changed when the war started.
